questions.text: At 36 weeks of gestation, a 28-year-old primigravida presents with reduced fetal movements. Cardiotocography indicates fetal heart rate deceleration due to uteroplacental insufficiency. On which day after fertilization is uteroplacental circulation established?

Description

questions.text: Which of the following endocrine effects is associated with the use of lithium?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Hypoth

 

LITHIUM

Lithium

Mood stabilizer

Absorption

Completely absorbed after oral administration

Plasma half-life

Initially 1-3 days, 2-4 days after long-term use

Indications

Manic episodes, bipolar depression, maintenance therapy, adjuvant in certain disorders

Side effects

Neurological, Endocrine, Renal, Dermatological, Others

Teratogenic effects

Risk of Ebstein's anomaly of tricuspid valve in exposed fetus

Drug interactions
  • ↑ Lithium concentration: Thiazide diuretics, K-sparing diuretics, ACE inhibitors, NSAIDs (except aspirin, sulindac)
  • ↓ Lithium concentration: Loop diuretics, osmotics , xanthine, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Checking lithium levels

Blood sample taken 12 hours 30 minutes after the last dose

Lithium levels
  • Therapeutic range - 0.5-1.5 mEq/L
  • In acute mania - 1 - 1.5 mEq/L
  • Maintenance - 0.6 - 1.2 mEq/L
  • Toxicity - > 1.5 mEq/L

Risk of lithium toxicity

Exceeding recommended dosage, renal impairment, drug interactions

Symptoms of toxicity

 

 

 
  • Mild to moderate: GI symptoms, CNS symptoms
  • Moderate to severe: GI and CNS symptoms
  • Severe: Generalized convulsions, renal failure

Treatment for toxicity

Stop lithium, correct hydration, removal of unabsorbed lithium, hemodialysis

Maintenance

Benzodiazepines (BZD)
  • Disulfiram (deterrent agent)

  • Naltrexone (opioid antagonist): Anticraving

Alcohol withdrawal hallucinosis, seizures, DT

 

Treatment
  • Short-acting BZD (e.g., Lorazepam)
  • Long-acting BZD (e.g., Chlordiazepoxide, Diazepam)
  • Liver disease: Glucuronidation-metabolized BZDs
  • Tremulousness and alcoholic hallucinosis: Chlordiazepoxide
  • Seizures: IV Diazepam
  • Delirium Tremens: IV Lorazepam
  • Other anti-craving agents: Ondansetron, Topiramate, Baclofen, Fluoxetine

Additional Recommendations
  • Thiamine supplementation
  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT)
  • Carbamazepine has also shown to be effective. Antipsychotics may be used to control severe aggitation and hallucinations.
  • Alcoholics Anonymous (AA)
  • Group Therapy
  • Family Therapy

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of scalp itching. He reports that many of his classmates are experiencing similar symptoms. On examination, gray scaly lesions are observed on the scalp, along with broken hair. Based on the clinical scenario, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A- Tinea

Tinea Capitis

Causative Agents

  • Dermatophyte fungi, commonly Trichophyton tonsurans, Microsporum spp.

Affected Population

  • Common in children, but can affect individuals of all ages.

Clinical Presentation

Scalp infection with various manifestations:

  • Gray Patch Type: Circular, scaly lesions, often with hair breakage.
  • Black Dot Type: Hair shafts with black dots, representing broken hairs.
  • Kerion Type: Pustules, nodules, and boggy swelling; may lead to scarring.

Contagiousness

Highly contagious, especially in the sharing of combs, hats, or personal items.

Diagnostic Tests

  • Wood's lamp examination may reveal fluorescence in some cases.
  • Microscopic examination of infected hairs with KOH preparation.
  • Culture of infected hairs for definitive identification.

Differential Diagnosis

  • Seborrheic dermatitis, psoriasis, and other scalp infections.

Treatment

  • Oral antifungal medications (griseofulvin, terbinafine, fluconazole).
  • Topical antifungal shampoos (ketoconazole, selenium sulfide).
  • Addressing environmental factors to prevent re-infection.

Correct Option D - Univ

Type of Vitiligo

VITILIGO

Generalized Vitiligo

Most common type of vitiligo

Depigmented patches occur symmetrically on both sides of the body

  • Can affect various body parts, including face, hands, feet, trunk, and extremities

Segmental Vitiligo
  • Occurs in specific segments or dermatomes on one side of the body

Usually starts at a young age and progresses for a limited period

Lesions may stabilize and not spread further

Focal Vitiligo

Characterized by isolated and scattered depigmented patches

Patches are typically limited in number and size

May affect specific areas like the face or hands

Mucosal Vitiligo

Affects mucous membranes, such as the lips, oral cavity, and genital areas

Lesions on mucous membranes appear white or milky

May occur independently or coexist with other types of vitiligo

Acrofacial Vitiligo

Involves acral areas (hands and feet) and the face

Often affects fingers, toes, and periungual regions

Facial involvement may include around the mouth, eyes, and ears

Mixed Vitiligo

Combination of different types of vitiligo

Multiple patterns of depigmentation coexist in the same individual

May include a combination of generalized, segmental, or focal vitiligo

Placement

Fixation

Indications

Disadvantages

ACIOL (Anterior Chamber Intraocular Lens)

Positioned in the anterior chamber

Anterior chamber angle

Aphakia or absence of posterior capsule support

Can provide good visual outcomes

Complications like corneal endothelial cell loss, iridocorneal touch, glare/halos, UGH syndrome

PCIOL (Posterior Chamber Intraocular Lens)

Positioned in the posterior chamber

Supported by the lens capsule or ciliary sulcus

Cataract surgery, replacing the natural lens

Excellent visual outcomes, stability

Requires intact lens capsule for proper fixation, may not correct astigmatism

Multifocal IOL (Multifocal Intraocular Lens)

Positioned in the posterior chamber

Supported by the lens capsule or ciliary sulcus

Reducing dependence on glasses for near and distance vision

Provides a range of vision without glasses

Visual disturbances like glare, halos, reduced contrast sensitivity

questions.text: A 7-year-old patient is diagnosed with a condition where one eye has reduced vision that is not correctable by glasses, reduced contrast sensitivity, and sunglass effect . In this patient, the fovea of one eye works in conjunction with the eccentric point of the other eye . What term is used to describe this phenomenon seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Abnormal retinal

Topic

Description

Amblyopia

Decrease in best-corrected visual activity

Types of Amblyopia

  • Strabismic Amblyopia: Deviation of one eye causing amblyopia

  • Form deprivation amblyopia: Opaque media obstructing light reaching the fovea

  • Refractive amblyopia: High anisometropia, uncorrected ametropia, or meridional amblyopia

Clinical Findings

  • Decrease in visual activity

  • Decreased contrast sensitivity

  • Decreased hyperacuity

  • Sunglass effect (decreased brightness in the amblyopic eye)

  • Crowding phenomenon

Treatment

  • Occlusion of the normal eye using patches or atropine

  • Age-based criteria for occlusion:

    • 1 Year = 1:1 i.e., occlude for one day and open for one day

    • 2 Years = 2:1 i.e., occlude for two days and open for one day

    • 3 Years = 3:1 i.e., occlude for three days and open for one day

    • 4 Years = 4:1 i.e., occlude for four days and open for one day

    • 5 Years = 5:1 i.e., occlude for five days and open for one day

    • 6 Years = 6:1 i.e., occlude for six days and open for one day

  • Additional methods:

    • Cam stimulators – They stimulate the amblyopic eye by showing various patterns to activate the fovea.

    • Pleoptics – To treat eccentric fixation by stimulating the fovea and blinding the eccentric point.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of dimunition of vision in his left eye for the past three months. questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to a concern about inward deviation of the eyes . Upon examination, the child exhibits a varying degree of convergent squint when looking at objects up close and in the distance, and on refraction it is noticed that the patient is suffering from high hypermetropia . Which type of esotropia is most likely present in this child?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Mixed accommodative

Types

Description

Refractive accommodative esotropia

  • Occurs due to uncorrected high hypermetropia, resulting in excessive accommodation and subsequent convergence squint. This convergent squint is the same for far and near.
  • Treatment: Treat hypermetropia

Non-refractive accommodative esotropia

  • Characterized by an increased AC/A ratio, leading to a greater squint for near vision than for distant vision.
  • Treatment: Assist accommodation using miotics or bifocal glasses.

Mixed accommodative esotropia

  • Involves both high hypermetropia and an increased AC/A ratio. It may contribute to convergence squint, but other factors may also be involved.
  • Treatment: refractive correction, Bifocals to relax accommodation.

Non-accommodative esotropia

  • Includes various types such as stress-induced esotropia, non-seeing eyes in children within 8 years, and overcorrection exotropia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with redness, pain, and mucopurulent discharge in the left eye . On examination, chemosis, and branched inflamed blood vessels are observed as seen in the image below. Which organism is the most likely cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - 

Most common causative organisms
  • Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae

Clinical features
  • Redness, pain, photophobia, purulent or mucopurulent discharge, etc.

Treatment
  • Antibiotics
  • Fluoroquinolones: Examples include ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin.
  • Aminoglycosides: Gentamicin and tobramycin are examples.
  • Macrolides: Erythromycin is a commonly used macrolide.

Investigation
  • Microbiologically (staining and culture) is the primary step,
  • PCR: to differentiate from viral infection if dx is inconclusive.
  • Biopsy

Clinical Signs
  • Congestion in palpebral conjunctiva
  • Conjunctival congestion
  • Chemosis
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage

Additional Information
  • Gonorrhea is the most dangerous infection in children.
  • Erythromycin or silver nitrate ointment in neonates for prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum due to gonorrhoea.
  • If there is systemic involvement, start 3rd generation cephalosporins.

Biliary type SOD: Pancreatic type SOD:

Type I:

  • Typical biliary-type pain

  • Dilated CBD >12 mm in diameter

  • Pancreatic-type pain
  • Amylase and/or lipase >2 times upper normal limit on at least 2 occasions during episodes of pain

  • Prolonged pancreatic drainage time (>9 min)

Type II:

  • One or two of the above criteria

Type II:

Type III:

Biliary type pain only

Type III:

Pancreatic type pain only

A 36-year-old woman G4P3L3 presents at full-term pregnancy with labour pains. On examination, she has a third-degree uterine prolapse. Which of the following complications can be expected during her labor?
questions.explanation:
Property Information
Definition Postpartum hemorrhage is excessive bleeding after childbirth, typically occurring within 24 hours following delivery. It is a leading cause of maternal mortality worldwide.
Types PPH can be categorized into two main types: primary PPH, which occurs within 24 hours of childbirth, and secondary PPH, which occurs between 24 hours and six weeks postpartum.
Causes Primary PPH is commonly caused by uterine atony (lack of uterine muscle tone), while secondary PPH may result from retained placental tissue or infections. Other factors, such as trauma or coagulation disorders, can also contribute.
Risk Factors Risk factors for PPH include multiple pregnancies (e.g., twins), large babies, prolonged labor, previous PPH, placental abnormalities, and certain medical conditions.
Signs and Symptoms Symptoms of PPH may include excessive vaginal bleeding, signs of shock (e.g., rapid pulse, low blood pressure), and pale skin.
Diagnosis Diagnosis is clinical and based on the amount and pattern of bleeding, vital signs, and physical examination. Blood tests and ultrasound may be used to identify the underlying cause.
Treatment Immediate treatment is essential and may include uterine massage, uterotonic medications (e.g., oxytocin), blood transfusions, manual removal of retained placental tissue, and surgical interventions like uterine artery embolization or hysterectomy.

questions.text: A woman at 48 years of age presents with the absence of menses for one year. The patient was vitally stable on examination, and her abdominopelvic assessment wasunremarkable. The patient was not using any medication and was not on any illicit drugs. Her pregnancy test is negative. On laboratory evaluation, her FSH level is 45 IU/mL . Which out of these is the most likely cause of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Ovarian failure secondary to cessation of pituitary secretion of gonadotropins

options.label: B
options.text: Ovarian failure secondary to the cessation of pituitary secretion of gonadotropins

options.label: D
options.text: Ovarian failure due to follicular exhaustion

questions.correct_answer: D. Ovarian failure due to follicular exhaustion
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of Menopause Description
Ovarian Aging As women age, the number of viable follicles in the ovaries decreases, leading to a decline in ovarian function. This results in reduced production of estrogen and progesterone.
Follicular Exhaustion With age, the pool of primordial follicles in the ovaries becomes depleted. As a result, fewer follicles are available to respond to hormonal signals, leading to diminished ovulation.
Decreased Hormone Production Menopause occurs when the ovaries produce less estrogen and progesterone. The decrease in these hormones leads to the cessation of regular menstrual cycles and the onset of menopause.
Decline in Inhibin B Production Inhibin B is a hormone produced by developing follicles in the ovaries. As the number of follicles decreases with age, inhibin B production also declines, affecting hormone regulation.
Hypothalamic Changes Changes in the hypothalamus contribute to the hormonal fluctuations during menopause. The hypothalamus plays a key role in regulating the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). As ovarian function declines, the feedback mechanism between the ovaries and hypothalamus becomes altered, leading to irregular hormone secretion.
A decline in Gonadotropin Feedback With decreased ovarian function, the feedback loop between the ovaries and pituitary gland becomes disrupted. The increased levels of FSH and LH (gonadotropins) reflect the reduced ovarian response to these hormones.
